Abstract

We study universal compression of sequences generated by monotonic distributions. We show that for a monotonic distribution over an alphabet of size kğ‘˜k, each probability parameter costs essentially 0.5â€‹logâ¡(n/k3)0.5ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜30.5\log(n/k^{3}) bits, where nğ‘›n is the coded sequence length, as long as k=oâ€‹(n1/3)ğ‘˜ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›13k=o(n^{1/3}). Otherwise, for k=Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›k=O(n), the total average sequence redundancy is Oâ€‹(n1/3+Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall. We then show that there exists a sub-class of monotonic distributions over infinite alphabets for which redundancy of Oâ€‹(n1/3+Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall is still achievable. This class contains fast decaying distributions, including many distributions over the integers and geometric distributions. For some slower decays, including other distributions over the integers, redundancy of oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) bits overall is achievable, where a method to compute specific redundancy rates for such distributions is derived. The results are specifically true for finite entropy monotonic distributions. Finally, we study individual sequence redundancy behavior assuming a sequence is governed by a monotonic distribution. We show that for sequences whose empirical distributions are monotonic, individual redundancy bounds similar to those in the average case can be obtained. However, even if the monotonicity in the empirical distribution is violated, diminishing per symbol individual sequence redundancies with respect to the monotonic maximum likelihood description length may still be achievable.

Index Terms: monotonic distributions, universal compression, average redundancy, individual redundancy, large alphabets, patterns.

1 Introduction

The classical setting of the universal lossless compression problem [5], [8], [9] assumes that a sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} of length nğ‘›n that was generated by a source ğœ½ğœ½\theta is to be compressed without knowledge of the particular ğœ½ğœ½\theta that generated xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} but with knowledge of the class Î›Î›\Lambda of all possible sources ğœ½ğœ½\theta. The average performance of any given code, that assigns a length function Lâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¿â‹…L(\cdot), is judged on the basis of the redundancy function Rnâ€‹(L,ğœ½)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘›ğ¿ğœ½R_{n}\left(L,\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\right), which is defined as the difference between the expected code length of Lâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¿â‹…L\left(\cdot\right) with respect to (w.r.t.) the given source probability mass function PÎ¸subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒP_{\theta} and the nğ‘›nth-order entropy of PÎ¸subscriptğ‘ƒğœƒP_{\theta} normalized by the length nğ‘›n of the uncoded sequence. A class of sources is said to be universally compressible in some worst sense if the redundancy function diminishes for this worst setting. Another approach to universal coding [29] considers the individual sequence redundancy R^nâ€‹(L,xn)subscript^ğ‘…ğ‘›ğ¿superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\hat{R}_{n}\left(L,x^{n}\right), defined as the normalized difference between the code length obtained by Lâ€‹(â‹…)ğ¿â‹…L(\cdot) for xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} and the negative logarithm of the maximum likelihood (ML) probability of the sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}, where the ML probability is within the class Î›Î›\Lambda. We thereafter refer to this negative logarithm as the ML description length of xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. The individual sequence redundancy is defined for each sequence that can be generated by a source ğœ½ğœ½\theta in the given class Î›Î›\Lambda.

Classical literature on universal compression [5], [8], [9], [23], [29] considered compression of sequences generated by sources over finite alphabets. In fact, it was shown by Kieffer [15] (see also [13]) that there are no universal codes (in the sense of diminishing redundancy) for sources over infinite alphabets. Later work (see, e.g., [21], [25]), however, bounded the achievable redundancies for identically and independently distributed (i.i.d.)Â sequences generated by sources over large and infinite alphabets. Specifically, while it was shown that the redundancy does not decay if the alphabet size is of the same order of magnitude as the sequence length nğ‘›n or greater, it was also shown that the redundancy does decay for alphabets of size oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n). 222For two functions fâ€‹(n)ğ‘“ğ‘›f(n) and gâ€‹(n)ğ‘”ğ‘›g(n), fâ€‹(n)=oâ€‹(gâ€‹(n))ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘›f(n)=o(g(n)) if âˆ€c,âˆƒn0for-allğ‘subscriptğ‘›0\forall c,\exists n_{0}, such that, âˆ€n>n0for-allğ‘›subscriptğ‘›0\forall n>n_{0}, fâ€‹(n)<câ€‹gâ€‹(n)ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘›f(n)<cg(n); fâ€‹(n)=Oâ€‹(gâ€‹(n))ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘”ğ‘›f(n)=O(g(n)) if âˆƒc,n0ğ‘subscriptğ‘›0\exists c,n_{0}, such that, âˆ€n>n0for-allğ‘›subscriptğ‘›0\forall n>n_{0}, 0â‰¤fâ€‹(n)â‰¤câ€‹gâ€‹(n)0ğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘›0\leq f(n)\leq cg(n); fâ€‹(n)=Î˜â€‹(gâ€‹(n))ğ‘“ğ‘›Î˜ğ‘”ğ‘›f(n)=\Theta(g(n)) if âˆƒc1,c2,n0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘›0\exists c_{1},c_{2},n_{0}, such that, âˆ€n>n0for-allğ‘›subscriptğ‘›0\forall n>n_{0}, c1â€‹gâ€‹(n)â‰¤fâ€‹(n)â‰¤c2â€‹gâ€‹(n)subscriptğ‘1ğ‘”ğ‘›ğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘2ğ‘”ğ‘›c_{1}g(n)\leq f(n)\leq c_{2}g(n).

While there is no universal code for infinite alphabets, recent work [20] demonstrated that if one considers the pattern of a sequence instead of the sequence itself, universal codes do exist in the sense of diminishing redundancy. A pattern of a sequence, first considered, to the best of our knowledge, in [1], is a sequence of indices, where the index Ïˆisubscriptğœ“ğ‘–\psi_{i} at time iğ‘–i represents the order of first occurrence of letter xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} in the sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. Further study of universal compression of patterns [20], [21], [26], [28] provided various lower and upper bounds to various forms of redundancy in universal compression of patterns. Another related study is that of compression of data, where the order of the occurring data symbols is not important, but their types and empirical counts are [30]-[31].

This paper considers universal compression of data sequences generated by distributions that are known a-priori to be monotonic. Hence, the order of probabilities of the source symbols is known in advance to both encoder and decoder and can be utilized as side information to improve universal compression performance. Monotonic distributions are common for distributions over the integers, including the geometric distribution and others. Such distributions do occur in image compression problems (see, e.g., [18], [19]), and in other applications that compress residual signals. A specific application one can consider for the results in this paper is compression of the list of last or first names in a given city of a given population. One can usually find some monotonicity for such a distribution in the given population, which both encoder and decoder may be aware of a-priori. For example, the last name â€œSmithâ€ can be expected to be much more common than the last name â€œShannonâ€. Another example is the compression of a sequence of observations of different species, where one has prior knowledge which species are more common, and which are rare. Finally, one can consider compressing data for which side information given to the decoder through a different channel gives the monotonicity order.

Unlike compression of patterns, Foster, Stine, and Wyner, showed in [10] that there are no universal block codes in the standard sense for the complete class of monotonic distributions. The main reason is that there exist such distributions, for which much of the statistical weight lies in symbols that have very low probability, and most of which will not occur in a given sequence. Thus, in practice, even though one has the prior knowledge of the monotonicity of the distribution, this monotonicity is not necessarily retained in an observed sequence. Therefore, actual coding can be very similar to compressing with infinite alphabets, and the additional prior knowledge of the monotonicity is not very helpful in reducing redundancy. Despite that, Foster, Stine, and Wyner demonstrated codes that obtained universal per-symbol redundancy of oâ€‹(1)ğ‘œ1o(1) as long as the source entropy is fixed (i.e., neither increasing with nğ‘›n nor infinite). However, instead of considering redundancy in the standard sense, the study of monotonic distributions resorted to studying relative redundancy, which bounds the ratio between average assigned code length and the source entropy. This approach dates back to work by Elias [7], Rissanen [22], and Ryabko [24].

The work in [10] studied coding sequences (or blocks) generated by i.i.d.Â monotonic distributions, and designed codes for which the relative block redundancy could be (upper) bounded. Unlike that work, the focus in [7], [22], and [24] was on designing codes that minimize the redundancy or relative redundancy for a single symbol generated by a monotonic distribution. Specifically, in [22], minimax codes, which minimize the relative redundancy for the worst possible monotonic distribution over a given alphabet size, were derived. In [24], it was shown that redundancy of Oâ€‹(logâ¡logâ¡k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(\log\log k), where kğ‘˜k is the alphabet size, can be obtained with minimax per-symbol codes. Very recent work [16] considered per-symbol codes that minimize an average redundancy over the class of monotonic distributions for a given alphabet size. Unlike [10], all these papers study per-symbol codes. Therefore, the codes designed always pay non-diminishing per-symbol redundancy.

A different line of work on monotonic distributions considered optimizing codes for a known monotonic distribution but with unknown parameters (see [18], [19] for design of codes for two-sided geometric distributions). In this line of work, the class of sources is very limited and consists of only the unknown parameters of a known distribution.

In this paper, we consider a general class of monotonic distributions that is not restricted to a specific type. We study standard block redundancy for coding sequences generated by i.i.d.Â monotonic distributions, i.e., a setting similar to the work in [10]. We do, however, restrict ourselves to smaller subsets of the complete class of monotonic distributions. First, we consider monotonic distributions over alphabets of size kğ‘˜k, where kğ‘˜k is either small w.r.t.Â nğ‘›n, or of Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n). Then, we extend the analysis to show that under minimal restrictions of the monotonic distribution class, there exist universal codes in the standard sense, i.e., with diminishing per-symbol redundancy. In fact, not only do universal codes exist, but under mild restrictions, they achieve the same redundancy as obtained for alphabets of size Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n). The restrictions on this subclass imply that some types of fast decaying monotonic distributions are included in it, and therefore, sequences generated by these distributions (without prior knowledge of either the distribution or of its parameters) can still be compressed universally in the class of monotonic distributions.

The main contributions of this paper are the development of codes and derivation of their upper bounds on the redundancies for coding i.i.d.Â sequences generated by monotonic distributions. Specifically, the paper gives complete characterization of the redundancy in coding with monotonic distributions over â€œsmallâ€ alphabets (k=oâ€‹(n1/3)ğ‘˜ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›13k=o(n^{1/3})) and â€œlargeâ€ alphabets (k=Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›k=O(n)). Then, it shows that these redundancy bounds carry over (in first order) to fast decaying distributions. Next, a code that achieves good redundancy rates for even slower decaying monotonic distributions is derived, and is used to study achievable redundancy rates for such distributions. Lower bounds are also presented to complete the characterization, and are shown to meet the upper bounds in the first three cases (small alphabets, large alphabets, and fast decaying distributions). The lower bounds turn out to result from lower bounds obtained for coding patterns. The relationship to patterns is demonstrated in the proofs of those lower bounds. Finally, individual sequences are considered. It is shown that under mild conditions, there exist universal codes w.r.t.Â the monotonic ML description length for sequences that contain the Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) more likely symbols, even if their empirical distributions are not monotonic.

The outline of this paper is as follows. SectionÂ 2 describes the notation and basic definitions. Then, in sectionÂ 3, lower bounds on the redundancy for monotonic distributions are derived. Next, in SectionÂ 4, we propose codes and upper bound their redundancy for coding monotonic distributions over small and large alphabets. These bounds are then extended to fast decaying monotonic distributions in SectionÂ 5. Finally, in SectionÂ 6, we consider individual sequence redundancy.

3 Lower Bounds

Lower bounds on various forms of the redundancy for the class of monotonic distributions can be obtained with slight modifications of the proofs for the lower bounds on the redundancy of coding patterns in [14], [20], [21], and [26]. The bounds are presented in the following three theorems. For the sake of completeness, the main steps of the proofs of the first two theorems are presented in appendices, and the proof of the third theorem is presented below. The reader is referred to [14], [20], [21], [25] and [26] for more details.

Theorem 1

Theorem 2

The bounds obtained are equal to those obtained for patterns because the first step (a)ğ‘(a) in (20) discards all the sequences whose contributions to Shtarkovâ€™s sum are different between patterns and monotonic distributions. A similar step is effectively done deriving the bounds for patterns. The difference is that in the case of patterns, components of Shtarkovâ€™s sum are reduced, but all are retained in the sum, while here, we omit components from the sum, corresponding to sequences with non-monotonic i.i.d.Â ML estimates. The analysis in [20] that also attains the second region of the bound in (8) is still valid here. It differs from the steps taken above by lower bounding a pattern probability by a larger probability than the ML i.i.d.Â probability corresponding to the pattern. The bound used in the derivation of Theorem 12 in [20] adds a multiplicative factor to each pattern probability which equals the number of sequences with the same pattern and an equal i.i.d.Â ML probability. However, this similar effect is included in Shtarkovâ€™s sum for monotonic distributions since all these sequences do have a corresponding i.i.d.Â ML estimate which is monotonic, and are thus not omitted by step (a)ğ‘(a) of the derivation.

The analysis in [14] yields the third region of the bound in (8), since, for kâ‰¥nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\geq n,

Inequality (a)ğ‘(a) holds because each pattern corresponds to at least one sequence whose ML probability parameter estimates are ordered, i.e., Î¸^iâ‰¥Î¸^i+1,âˆ€isubscript^ğœƒğ‘–subscript^ğœƒğ‘–1for-allğ‘–\hat{\theta}_{i}\geq\hat{\theta}_{i+1},\forall i, where the most probable index represents i=1ğ‘–1i=1, the second most probable index i=2ğ‘–2i=2, and so on. Note that the sum element on the right hand side is for a probability of a sequence, not a pattern, but the sum is over all patterns. The left hand side also includes sequences for which the probabilities are unordered. Furthermore, exchanging the letters that correspond to two indices with the same occurrence count will not violate monotonicity. Thus the inequality follows. Step (b)ğ‘(b) in (22) is taken from [14], where the sum on the left hand side was shown to equal the right hand side. This was true when summing over all patterns with up to nğ‘›n indices, thus requiring kâ‰¥nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\geq n. Note that this requirement does not mean that nğ‘›n distinct symbols must occur in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}, only that the maximal symbol in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} is nğ‘›n or greater. This concludes the proof of TheoremÂ 3. â–¡â–¡\Box

4 Upper Bounds for Small and Large Alphabets

In this section, we demonstrate codes that asymptotically achieve the lower bounds for ğœ½âˆˆâ„³kğœ½subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k} and k=Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›k=O(n). We begin with a theorem that shows the achievable redundancies, and devote the remainder of the section to describing the codes and deriving upper bounds on their redundancies. The theorem is stated assuming no initial knowledge of kğ‘˜k. The proof first considers the setting where kğ‘˜k is known, and then shows how the same bounds are achieved even when kğ‘˜k is unknown in advance, but as long as it satisfies the conditions.

Theorem 4

Fix an arbitrarily small Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and let nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. Then, there exist a code with length function Lâˆ—â€‹(â‹…)superscriptğ¿â‹…L^{*}\left(\cdot\right) that achieves redundancy

(23)

for i.i.d.Â sequences generated by any source ğ›‰âˆˆâ„³kğ›‰subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}_{k}.

Slightly tighter bounds are possible in the first and second regions and between them. The bounds presented, however, are inclusive for each of the regions. Note that the third region contains the second, but if k=oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘›k=o(n), a tighter bound is possible in the second region. The code designed to code a sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} is a two part code [23] that quantizes a distribution that minimizes the cost, and uses it to code xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. The total redundancy cost consists of the cost of describing the quantized distribution and the quantization cost. The second is bounded through the quantized true distribution of the sequence, which cannot result in lower cost than that of the chosen distribution (which minimizes the cost). In order to achieve the low costs of the lower bound, the probability parameters are quantized non-uniformly, where the smaller the probability the finer the quantization. This approach was used in [25] and [26] to obtain upper bounds on the redundancy for coding over large alphabets and for coding patterns, respectively. The method used in [25] and [26], however, is insufficient here, because it still results in too many quantization points due to the polynomial growth in quantization spacing. Here, we use an exponential growth as the parameters increase. This general idea was used in [28] to improve an upper bound on the redundancy of coding patterns. Here, however, we improve on the method presented in [28]. Another key step in the proof here is the fact that since both encoder and decoder know the order of the probabilities a-priori, this order need not be coded. It is sufficient to encode the quantized probabilities of the monotonic distribution, and the decoder can identify which probability is associated with which symbol using the monotonicity of the distribution.

The proof up to this point assumes that kğ‘˜k is known in advance. This is important for the code resulting in the bound for the first region because the quantization grid depends on kğ‘˜k. Specifically, if in building the grid, kğ‘˜k is underestimated, the description cost of ğ‹ğ‹\varphi increases. If kğ‘˜k is overestimated, the quantization cost will increase. Also, if the code of the second region is used for a smaller kğ‘˜k, a larger bound than necessary results. To solve this, the optimization that chooses Lâˆ—â€‹(xn)superscriptğ¿superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›L^{*}\left(x^{n}\right) is done over all possible values of kğ‘˜k (greater than or equal to the maximal symbol occurring in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}), i.e., every greater kğ‘˜k in the first region, and the construction of the code for the other regions. For every kğ‘˜k in the first region, a different construction is done, using the appropriate kğ‘˜k to determine the spacing in each interval. The value of kğ‘˜k yielding the shortest code word is then used, and Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) additional bits are used at the prefix of the code to inform the decoder which kğ‘˜k is used. The analysis continues as before. This does not change the redundancy to first order, giving all three regions of the bound in (23), even if kğ‘˜k is unknown in advance. This concludes the proof of TheoremÂ 4. â–¡â–¡\Box

5 Upper Bounds for Fast Decaying Distributions

This section shows that with some mild conditions on the source distribution, the same redundancy upper bounds achieved for finite monotonic distributions can be achieved even if the monotonic distribution is over an infinite alphabet. The key observation that allows this is that a distribution that decays fast enough will result in only a small number of occurrences of unlikely letters in a sequence. These letters may very likely be out of order, but since there are very few of them, they can be handled without increasing the asymptotic behavior of the coding cost. More precisely, fast decaying monotonic distributions can be viewed as if they have some effective bounded alphabet size, where occurrences of symbols outside this limited alphabet are rare. We present two theorems and a corollary that show how one can upper bound the redundancy obtained when coding with some unknown distribution. The first theorem provides a slightly stronger bound (with smaller coefficient) even for k=Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›k=O(n), where the smaller coefficient is attained by improved bounding, that more uniformly weights the quantization cost for minimal probabilities. In the weaker version of the results presented here, if the distribution decays slower and there are more low probability symbols, the redundancy order does increase due to the penalty of identifying these symbols in a sequence. However, we show, consistently with the results in [10], that as long as the entropy of the source is finite, a universal code, in the sense of diminishing redundancy per symbol, does exist. We begin with stating the two theorems and the corollary, then the proofs are presented. The section is concluded with three examples of typical monotonic distributions over the integers, to which the bounds are applied.

5.1 Upper Bounds

We begin with some notation. Fix an arbitrary small Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and let nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. (Note that Ï=(logâ¡m)/(logâ¡n)ğœŒğ‘šğ‘›\rho=(\log m)/(\log n).) Let

Theorem 5

I. Fix an arbitrarily small Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and let nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. Let xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} be generated by an i.i.d.Â monotonic distribution ğ›‰âˆˆâ„³ğ›‰â„³\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}\in{\cal M}. If there exists mâˆ—superscriptğ‘šm^{*}, such that,

for the monotonic distribution ğ›‰ğ›‰\theta.

TheoremÂ 5 implies that if a monotonic distribution decays fast enough, its effective alphabet size does not exceed Oâ€‹(nÏ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›ğœŒO(n^{\rho}), and, as long as ÏğœŒ\rho is fixed, bounds of the same order as those obtained for finite alphabets are achievable. Specifically, very fast decaying distributions, although over infinite alphabets, may even behave like monotonic distributions with oâ€‹(n1/3)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›13o\left(n^{1/3}\right) symbols. The condition in (52) merely means that the cost that a code would obtain in order to code very rare symbols, that are larger than the effective alphabet size, is negligible w.r.t.Â the total cost obtained from other, more likely, symbols. Note that for m=nğ‘šğ‘›m=n, the bound is tighter than that of the third region of TheoremÂ 4, and a constant of 5/9595/9 replaces 2/3232/3. The second part of the theorem states that if the decay is slow, but the cost of coding rare symbols is still diminishing per symbol, a universal code still exists for such distributions. However, in this case the redundancy will be dominated by coding the rare (out of order) symbols. This result leads to the following corollary:

Corollary 1

As nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty, sequences generated by monotonic distributions with HÎ¸â€‹(X)=Oâ€‹(1)subscriptğ»ğœƒğ‘‹ğ‘‚1H_{\theta}(X)=O(1) are universally compressible in the average sense.

CorollaryÂ 1 shows that sequences generated by finite entropy monotonic distributions can be compressed in the average with diminishing per symbol redundancy. This result is consistent with the results shown in [10].

While TheoremÂ 5 bounds the redundancy decay rate with two extremes, a more general theorem can be used to provide some best redundancy decay rate that a code can be designed to adapt to for some unknown monotonic distribution that governs the data. As the examples at the end of this section show, the next theorem is very useful for slower decaying distributions.

Theorem 6

Fix an arbitrarily small Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and let nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. for coding sequences generated by the source ğ›‰ğ›‰\theta.

We continue with proving the two theorems and the corollary.

Proof : The idea of the proof of both theorems is to separate the more likely symbols from the unlikely ones. First, the code determines the point of separation m=nÏğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘›ğœŒm=n^{\rho}. (Note that ÏğœŒ\rho can be greater than 111.) Then, all symbols iâ‰¤mğ‘–ğ‘ši\leq m are considered likely and are quantized in a similar manner as in the codes for smaller alphabets. Unlike bounded alphabets, though, a more robust grid is used here to allow larger values of mğ‘šm. Coding of occurrences of these symbols uses the quantized probabilities. The unlikely symbols are coded hierarchically. They are first merged into a single symbol, and then are coded within this symbol, where the full cost of conveying to the decoder which rare symbols occur in the sequence is required. Thus, they are presented giving their actual value. As long as the decay is fast enough, the average cost of conveying these symbols becomes negligible w.r.t.Â the cost of coding the likely symbols. If the decay is slower, but still fast enough, as the case described in condition (54), the coding cost of the rare symbols dominates the redundancy, but still diminishing redundancy can be achieved. In order to determine the best value of mğ‘šm for a given sequence, all values are tried and the one yielding the shortest description is used for coding the specific sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}.

Let mâ‰¥2ğ‘š2m\geq 2 determine the number of likely symbols in the alphabet. For a given mğ‘šm, define

Sm=â–³âˆ‘i>mÎ¸i,superscriptâ–³subscriptğ‘†ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptğœƒğ‘–S_{m}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\sum_{i>m}\theta_{i}, (57)

as the total probability of the remaining symbols. Given ğœ½ğœ½\theta, mğ‘šm and Smsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘šS_{m}, a probability

5.2 Examples

We demonstrate the use of the bounds of TheoremsÂ 5 andÂ 6 with three typical distributions over the integers. We specifically show that the redundancy rate of Oâ€‹(n1/3+Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€O\left(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}\right) bits overall is achievable when coding many of the typical monotonic distributions, and, in fact, for many distributions faster convergence rates are achievable with the codes provided in proving the theorems above. The assumption that very few unlikely symbols are likely to appear in a sequence generated by a monotonic distribution, which is reflected in the conditions in (52) and (54), is very realistic even in practical examples. Specifically, in the phone book example, there may be many rare names, but only very few of them may occur in a certain city, and the more common names constitute most of any possible phone book sequence.

5.2.1 Fast Decaying Distributions Over the Integers

Consider the monotonic distributions over the integers of the form,

Corollary 2

6 Individual Sequences

In this section, we first show that individual sequences whose empirical distributions obey the monotonicity constraints can be universally compressed as well as the average case. We then study compression of sequences whose empirical distributions may diverge from monotonic. We demonstrate that under mild conditions, similar in nature to those of TheoremsÂ 5 andÂ 6, redundancy that diminishes (slower than in the average case) w.r.t.Â the monotonic ML description length can be obtained. However, these results are only useful when the monotonic ML description length diverges only slightly from the (standard) ML description length of a sequence, i.e., the empirical distribution of a sequence only mildly violates monotonicity. Otherwise, the penalty of using an incorrect monotone model overwhelms the redundancy gain. We begin with sequences that obey the monotonicity constraints.

Theorem 8

for every xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}.

TheoremÂ 8 shows that if one can find a relatively small effective alphabet of the symbols that occur in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}, and the symbols outside this alphabet are small enough, xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} can be described with diminishing per-symbol redundancy w.r.t.Â its monotonic ML description length. This implies that as long as the occurring symbols are not too large, there exist a universal code w.r.t.Â a monotonic ML distribution for any such sequence xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. This is unlike standard individual sequence compression w.r.t.Â the i.i.d.Â ML description length. Specifically, if the effective alphabet size is Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n), and only a small number of symbols which are only polynomial in nğ‘›n occur, the universality cost is Oâ€‹(nâ€‹(logâ¡n)2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2O(\sqrt{n}(\log n)^{2}) bits overall, which gives diminishing per-symbol redundancy of Oâ€‹((logâ¡n)2/n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘›O((\log n)^{2}/\sqrt{n}). This redundancy is much better than what can be achieved in standard compression. The penalty, of course, is when the empirical distribution of an individual sequence diverges significantly away from a monotonic one. While the monotonic redundancy can be made diminishing under mild conditions, there is a non-diminishing divergence cost by using the monotonic ML description length instead of the ML description length in that case. This implies that one should compress a sequence as generated by a monotonic distribution only if the total description length required to code xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} as such is shorter than the total description length required to code xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} with standard methods. As shown in the proof of TheoremÂ 8, one prefix bit can inform the decoder which type of description is used.

TheoremÂ 8 shows that as long as the effective alphabet size is polynomial in nğ‘›n, Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5 optimizes the third region of the upper bound, thus yielding the rate shown above, unless very large symbols occur in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. For small effective alphabets (the first region), there is no redundancy gain in using the monotonic ML description length over the ML description length. The reason, again, is that the bound is obtained for cases where the actual empirical distribution of a sequence may not be monotonic. One can still use an i.i.d.Â ML estimate w.r.t.Â only the effective alphabet, if the additional cost of symbols outside this alphabet is negligible, to better code such sequences. TheoremÂ 8 also shows that if a very large symbol, such as i=anğ‘–superscriptğ‘ğ‘›i=a^{n}; a>1ğ‘1a>1, occurs in xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}, xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} cannot be universally compressed even w.r.t.Â its monotonic ML description length. This is because it is impossible to avoid the cost of (1+Îµ)â€‹logâ¡i=(1+Îµ)â€‹nâ€‹logâ¡a1ğœ€ğ‘–1ğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘(1+\varepsilon)\log i=(1+\varepsilon)n\log a bits to describe this symbol to the decoder. The bound above and its proof below give a very powerful method to individually compress sequences that have an almost monotonic empirical distribution but may have some limited disorder, for which the monotonic ML description length diverges only negligibly from the ML description length.

Proof of TheoremÂ 8: The proof follows the same steps as the proof of TheoremsÂ 5 andÂ 6. Each value of mğ‘šm is tested and the best one is chosen, where the same coding costs described in the mentioned proof are computed for each mğ‘šm. In addition, one can test the cost of coding xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} using the description lengths for both ğœ½^^ğœ½\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} and ğœ½^â„³subscript^ğœ½â„³\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}. Then, one bit can be used to relay which ML estimator is used. If ğœ½^^ğœ½\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}} is used, the codes for coding individual sequences over large alphabets in either [21] or [25] can be used. In the first region in (92), the bound in [25] is obtained since logâ¡PÎ¸^â€‹(xn)â‰¥logâ¡PÎ¸^â„³â€‹(xn)subscriptğ‘ƒ^ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒsubscript^ğœƒâ„³superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\log P_{\hat{\theta}}\left(x^{n}\right)\geq\log P_{\hat{\theta}_{{\cal M}}}\left(x^{n}\right) for every xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n}. This bound yields smaller redundancy for this region than that obtained using ğœ½^â„³subscript^ğœ½â„³\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}} if ğœ½^â„³â‰ ğœ½^subscript^ğœ½â„³^ğœ½\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}_{{\cal M}}\neq\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$}}. It implies that for small alphabets, if xnsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x^{n} does not have an empirical monotonic distribution, it is better coded, even in terms of universal coding redundancy, using standard universal compression methods without taking advantage of a monotonicity assumption.

For the other two regions, we start with a lemma.

7 Summary and Conclusions

Universal compression of sequences generated by monotonic distributions was studied. We showed that for finite alphabets, if one has the prior knowledge of the monotonicity of a distribution, one can reduce the cost of universality. For alphabets of oâ€‹(n1/3)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›13o(n^{1/3}) letters, this cost reduces from 0.5â€‹logâ¡(n/k)0.5ğ‘›ğ‘˜0.5\log(n/k) bits per each unknown probability parameter to 0.5â€‹logâ¡(n/k3)0.5ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜30.5\log(n/k^{3}) bits per each unknown probability parameter. Otherwise, for alphabets of Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) letters, one can compress such sources with overall redundancy of Oâ€‹(n1/3+Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits. This is a significant decrease in redundancy from Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) or Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) bits overall that can be achieved if no side information is available about the source distribution. Redundancy of Oâ€‹(n1/3+Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›13ğœ€O(n^{1/3+\varepsilon}) bits overall can also be achieved for much larger alphabets including infinite alphabets for fast decaying monotonic distributions. Sequences generated by slower decaying distributions can also be compressed with diminishing per-symbol redundancy costs under some mild conditions and specifically if they have finite entropy rates. Examples for well-known monotonic distributions demonstrated how the diminishing redundancy decay rates can be computed by applying the bounds that were derived. Finally, the average case results were extended to individual sequences. Similar convergence rates were shown for sequences that have empirical monotonic distributions. Furthermore, universal redundancy bounds w.r.t.Â the monotonic ML description length of a sequence were also derived for the more general case. Under some mild conditions, these bounds still exhibit diminishing per-symbol redundancies.

Appendix Appendix B â€“Â Â  Proof of TheoremÂ 2

To prove TheoremÂ 2, we use the random-coding strong version of the redundancy-capacity theorem [17]. The idea is similar to the weak version used in Appendix A. We assume that grids ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} of points are uniformly distributed over â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}, and one grid is selected randomly. Then, a point in the selected grid is randomly selected under a uniform prior to generate Xnsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n}. Showing distinguishability within a selected grid, for every possible random choice of ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, implies that a lower bound on the cardinality of ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} for every possible choice is essentially a lower bound on the overall sequence redundancy for most sources in â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}.

The construction of ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} is identical to that used in [26] to construct a grid of sources that generate patterns. We pack spheres of radius nâˆ’0.5â€‹(1âˆ’Îµ)superscriptğ‘›0.51ğœ€n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)} in the parameter space defining â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}. The set ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} consists of the center points of the spheres. To cover the space â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}, we randomly select a random shift of the whole lattice under a uniform distribution. The cardinality of ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} is lower bounded by the relation between the volume of â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}, which equals (as shown in [26]) 1/[(kâˆ’1)!â€‹k!]1delimited-[]ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜1/[(k-1)!k!], and the volume of a single sphere, with factoring also of a packing density (see, e.g., [2]). This yields eq.Â (55) in [26],

Mâ„³kâ‰¥1(kâˆ’1)!â‹…k!â‹…Vkâˆ’1â€‹(nâˆ’0.5â€‹(1âˆ’Îµ))â‹…2kâˆ’1,subscriptğ‘€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜1â‹…â‹…ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘›0.51ğœ€superscript2ğ‘˜1M_{{\cal M}_{k}}\geq\frac{1}{(k-1)!\cdot k!\cdot V_{k-1}\left(n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)}\right)\cdot 2^{k-1}}, (B.1)

where Vkâˆ’1â€‹(nâˆ’0.5â€‹(1âˆ’Îµ))subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘›0.51ğœ€V_{k-1}\left(n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)}\right) is the volume of a kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1 dimensional sphere with radius nâˆ’0.5â€‹(1âˆ’Îµ)superscriptğ‘›0.51ğœ€n^{-0.5(1-\varepsilon)} (see, e.g., [2] for computation of this volume).

For distinguishability, it is sufficient to show that there exists an estimator ğš¯^gâ€‹(Xn)âˆˆğ›€â„³ksubscript^ğš¯ğ‘”superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›subscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n})\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} such that limnâ†’âˆPÎ˜â€‹[ğš¯^gâ€‹(Xn)â‰ ğš¯]=0subscriptâ†’ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ƒÎ˜delimited-[]subscript^ğš¯ğ‘”superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›ğš¯0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}P_{\Theta}\left[\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n})\neq\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}\right]=0 for every choice of ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} and for every choice of ğš¯âˆˆğ›€â„³kğš¯subscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}\in\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}. This is already shown in LemmaÂ 4.1 in [25] for a larger grid ğ›€ğ›€\Omega of i.i.d.Â sources, which is constructed identically to ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} over the complete kâˆ’1ğ‘˜1k-1 dimensional probability simplex. Therefore, by the monotonicity requirement, for every ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, there exists such ğ›€ğ›€\Omega, such that ğ›€â„³kâŠ†ğ›€subscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜ğ›€\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}\subseteq\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}. Since LemmaÂ 4.1 in [25] holds for ğ›€ğ›€\Omega, it then must also hold for the smaller grid ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}. Note that distinguishability is easier to prove here than for patterns because ğš¯^gâ€‹(Xn)subscript^ğš¯ğ‘”superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›\hat{\mbox{\boldmath$\Theta$}}_{g}(X^{n}) is obtained directly form Xnsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X^{n} and not from its pattern as in [26]. Now, since all the conditions of the strong random-coding version of the redundancy-capacity theorem hold, taking the logarithm of bound in (B.1), absorbing low order terms in Îµğœ€\varepsilon, and normalizing by nğ‘›n, leads to the first region of the bound in (7). More detailed steps follow those found in [26].

The second region of the bound is handled in a manner related to the second region of the bound of TheoremÂ 1. However, here, we cannot simply set the probability of all symbols i>kmğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘ši>k_{m} to zero, because all possible valid sources must be included in one of the grids ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}} to generate a complete covering of â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k}. As was done in [26], we include sources with Î¸i>0subscriptğœƒğ‘–0\theta_{i}>0 for i>kmğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘ši>k_{m} in the grids ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, but do not include them in the lower bound on the number of grid points. Instead, for k>kmğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk>k_{m}, we bound the number of points in a kmsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk_{m}-dimensional cut of â„³ksubscriptâ„³ğ‘˜{\cal M}_{k} for which the remaining kâˆ’kmğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk-k_{m} components of ğœ½ğœ½\theta are very small (and insignificant). This analysis is valid also for k>nğ‘˜ğ‘›k>n. Distinguishability for k>kmğ‘˜subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk>k_{m} is shown for i.i.d.Â non-monotonically restricted distributions in the proof of LemmaÂ 6.1 in [26]. As before, it carries over to monotonic distributions, since as before, for each ğ›€â„³ksubscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}, there exists an unrestricted corresponding ğ›€ğ›€\Omega, such that ğ›€â„³kâŠ†ğ›€subscriptğ›€subscriptâ„³ğ‘˜ğ›€\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}_{{\cal M}_{k}}\subseteq\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$}. The choice of km=0.5â€‹(n1âˆ’Îµ/Ï€)1/3subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘š0.5superscriptsuperscriptğ‘›1ğœ€ğœ‹13k_{m}=0.5(n^{1-\varepsilon}/\pi)^{1/3} gives the maximal bound w.r.t.Â kğ‘˜k. Since, again, all conditions of the strong version of the redundancy-capacity theorem are satisfied, the second region of the bound is obtained. Again, more detailed steps can be found in [26]. This concludes the proof of TheoremÂ 2. â–¡â–¡\Box
